Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: They appear at a minor hearing where the stakes are relatively low
Story:
I sat at my desk, headset pressing into my ear, the script for our new service open in front of me. As a telemarketer, I was expected to handle customer objections smoothly, but today, every call seemed to veer off-script. Prospects wanted technical details—real answers, not the vague reassurances my script offered. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind: “Stick to the script, don’t improvise.” But I could hear the frustration in the customers’ voices, and it gnawed at me.

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder: I had a minor hearing to attend as an advocate in an hour. The stakes were low, but my client still deserved to be represented effectively. I was supposed to be their voice, to fight for their interests, no matter how small the case.

I felt pulled in two directions. On one hand, I was expected to be a compliant telemarketer, following the company’s rigid guidelines. On the other, I was an advocate, trained to dig deeper, to answer questions, to stand up for people. The demands clashed inside me, and I stared at the clock, heart pounding, unsure which role I could honor without betraying the other.
